Award.AwardTitle: High-Temperature Surface Dynamics of Transition-Metal Oxides

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to determine the atomic-scale mechanisms responsible for high-temperature surface stability of catalytically-active transition-metal oxides such as titanium dioxide (TiO2). Since catalytic performance depends critically on the surface atomic structure and composition, a stable surface with desired stoichiometry is critical for superior lifetime performance. Relatively little is known concerning the effect of gas chemistry on high-temperature surface composition and defect structure of TiO2. This investigation will use in situ high-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and low-energy electron microscopy techniques and establish the dynamics of surface morphological, structural, and compositional evolution on rutile-structured TiO2(110).

If successful, this research program will lead to the development of high-performance transition-metal oxide catalysts and catalyst support materials, thermophotovoltaics, and other devices. The project will encourage the participation of underrepresented students and promote awareness among high-school students to pursue higher education in science and engineering at UCLA. Research results will be integrated into courses for the benefit of students and disseminated through presentations and publications. A focused session emphasizing in situ microscopy studies of surface and interface dynamics will be organized to enhance awareness about this topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High-Temperature Surface Dynamics of Transition-Metal Oxides

 

Suneel Kodambaka, University of California Los Angeles

 

The research objective of this grant is to determine the atomic-scale mechanisms responsible for thermochemical stability of catalytically-active transition-metal oxides. Since catalytic performance depends critically on the surface atomic structure and composition, a stable surface with desired stoichiometry is critical for superior lifetime performance. Relatively little is known concerning the effect of gas chemistry on surface compositional and structural stabilities of these materials. This NSF-funded project focused first on using in situ high-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy techniques and investigated the dynamics of surface morphological, structural, and compositional evolution on rutile-structured titanium dioxide while subjected to high temperatures in oxidizing, carburizing, and vacuum environments. Later studies focused on other catalytically-active oxides of copper, zinc, and molybdenum (CuO, ZnO, and MoO3) and investigated the growth of copper oxide (CuO), thermochemical stability of molybdenum oxide (MoO3), and detailed structural and morphological characterization of ZnO nanostructures. In addition to these experiments on oxides, detailed high-resolution transmission electron microscopy characterization of pyrite nanospheres, silicon quantum dots, and platinum and palladium nanocrystals that are of interest in catalysis were carried out. Finally, an unexpected outcome of electron microscopy investigations led to variable-temperature electron microscopy studies of liquid gallium droplet dynamics.

 All of these research efforts involved the participation of a female graduate student who has obtained her doctoral degree. Three undergraduate students were provided with opportunities in engage in research activities. They gained hands-on experience with the use of scanning electron microscopy and x-ray diffraction techniques. Two of these students are currently pursuing graduate studies. Research results will presented in the classroom lectures and disseminated through presentations and peer-revieiwed journal publications.
